raw_response.summary_short: Major art museum in Denver with rotating exhibitions spanning Impressionism, contemporary practice, and Latin American art; plan about a half day.
raw_response.summary_long: The Denver Art Museum is a leading art museum in Denver. Current programming highlights include “The Honest Eye: Camille Pissarro’s Impressionism” (through Feb 8, 2026), contemporary-focused shows such as “Andrea Carlson: A Constant Sky” and “Fuse Box: Sarah Sze,” and “A Century of Art in Latin America.” The museum also promotes frequent public programs and curator-led events via its calendar, supporting deeper engagement beyond gallery viewing. Allocate roughly a half day for a focused visit built around one or two exhibitions.

collection_highlights.title: The Honest Eye: Camille Pissarro’s Impressionism (through Feb 8, 2026)
collection_highlights.description: Exhibition centered on Pissarro and Impressionism.

collection_highlights.title: Andrea Carlson: A Constant Sky (now on view)
Fuse Box: Sarah Sze (now on view)
A Century of Art in Latin America (now on view)
collection_highlights.description: Survey-style exhibition focused on Latin American art.

collection_highlights.title: What We’ve Been Up To: Landscape (Jun 8, 2025 – Jan 4, 2026)

visitor_tips: Plan a half-day visit to cover one or two exhibitions at a comfortable pace.
Check the museum calendar for curator-led tours and after-hours programs tied to exhibitions.
If you’re prioritizing, build your route around the Pissarro Impressionism show and one contemporary exhibition.

tour_planning_scores.scoring_rationale: Evidence points to strong temporary programming in both Impressionism (Pissarro) and contemporary art (Carlson, Sze), plus a Latin America survey. The presence of curator-led and after-hours events supports above-average educational value; collection depth/quality are inferred conservatively from the breadth of exhibitions shown.
